fields.description:
h3. Summary

Bitbucket Server in-browser editor unexpectedly replaces CRLF at the end of file with LF.
h3. Environment
 * [Bitbucket Server 4.13|https://www.atlassian.com/blog/bitbucket/bitbucket-server-4-13-in-browser-editing-and-more] or newer versions
 ** Verified with v5.5.5 hosted on Ubuntu 14.04.5 LTS and Git version 2.13.0

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # (Local) Create a file containing lines with CRLF
{code:none}
# The special character "\r\n" stands for CRLF. And "\c" suppresses newline
$ echo -e "North\r\nSouth\r\nWest\r\n\c" > example.txt
# Verify the file ends with "^M$"
$ cat -e example.txt
North^M$
South^M$
West^M$
# Verify the file ends with "0d 0a" in hexadecimal binary
$ hexdump -C example.txt
00000000  4e 6f 72 74 68 0d 0a 53  6f 75 74 68 0d 0a 57 65  |North..South..We|
00000010  73 74 0d 0a                                       |st..|
00000014
{code}

 # (Local) Git commit and push the file to Bitbucket Server
 # (Remote) Open example.txt and add "East" to the second line by in-browser editor
 # (Local) Git pull
 # (Local) Check the eol type at end of file is changed to LF from CRLF
{code:none}
# Verify the file ends with "$" but not "^M$"
$ cat -e example.txt
North^M$
East^M$
South^M$
West$
# Now the file ends with "0a" in hexadecimal binary
$ hexdump -C example.txt
00000000  4e 6f 72 74 68 0d 0a 45  61 73 74 0d 0a 53 6f 75  |North..East..Sou|
00000010  74 68 0d 0a 57 65 73 74  0a                       |th..West.|
00000019
{code}

h3. Expected Results

The edited file keeps CRLF at the end of file:
{code:none}
$ cat -e example.txt
North^M$
East^M$
South^M$
West^M$
{code}
h3. Actual Results

CRLF at the end of file is replaced with LF.
{noformat}
$ cat -e example.txt
North^M$
East^M$
South^M$
West$
{noformat}
h3. Notes
 * Owing to these configurations in git, other lines except the end of file are intact
 ** [core.autocrlf=input|https://git-scm.com/docs/git-config#git-config-coreautocrlf]
 ** [core.safecrlf=warn|https://git-scm.com/docs/git-config#git-config-coresafecrlf]
 * In-browser editor inserts newline (LF) when the file doesn't contain eol character
{code:none}
echo 'Foo\c' > example.txt
{code}

h3. Workaround
 * Edit files in other editor but not in-browser editor if you want to keep CRLF
fields.summary: In-browser editor replace the eol at the end of file with LF regardless of existing eol type

fields.description:
I love the "View the full source of this file" feature; one problem, though, is that when we return, we've lost the context on the left side "Diff" tab of the web page.  As a result, we have to scroll all the way down to the file we were reviewing.

Please restore the position upon returning from "View the full source of this file".
fields.summary: Lose context on left side of "Diff" tab after "View the full source of this file"

fields.description:
I love the "Find text in diff and context lines" feature.

So that we can get more focused/granular results, it would be great if we could specify 'Match whole word'; while doing that, it would be great if you could also implement the ability to do a regular expression search.  Ability to specify case-sensitive searches would also be great.
fields.summary: Ability to specify 'Match whole word' in "Find text in diff and context lines" feature

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Bitbucket is inconsistent with Jira and other Atlassian products in the way you search for a user in the user picker for reviewers of pull requests. If you search using <last name> <first name> in the PR creation, the user does not appear in the results.

h3. Suggested Solution

Support searching for a reviewer by reversing first name and last name order in user picker for pull requests
fields.summary: Reviewer user picker first and last name reversal

fields.description:
h3. Summary
The username field in the {{atlassian-bitbucket-access.log}} is empty and does not contain any information when performing Git operations via ssh.

This applies to operations performed by using an SSH Key or an Access Key.


h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Perform a Git operation via ssh (e.g. clone or push a repository)

h3. Expected Results
The username ({{charlie}} in the SSH Key example) and an id associated with the access key ({{b69a0c4a7aa114a0}} in the Access Key one) is available in the access log.

Git operation using an +SSH Key+
{noformat}
# push operation
172.17.0.1 | ssh | i@YJILN0x263x126x0 | charlie | 2018-01-04 04:23:13,510 | SSH - git-receive-pack '/tp1/tp_rep1.git' | - | - | - | - | - | - | 1nc5d5q |
172.17.0.1 | ssh | o@YJILN0x263x126x0 | charlie | 2018-01-04 04:23:14,131 | SSH - git-receive-pack '/tp1/tp_rep1.git' | - | 0 | 855 | 190 | push, ssh:user:id:1 | 621 | 1nc5d5q |
# clone operation
172.17.0.1 | ssh | i@YJILN0x263x127x0 | charlie | 2018-01-04 04:23:34,325 | SSH - git-upload-pack '/tp1/tp_rep1.git' | - | - | - | - | - | - | o9qsm4 |
172.17.0.1 | ssh | o@YJILN0x263x127x0 | charlie | 2018-01-04 04:23:34,482 | SSH - git-upload-pack '/tp1/tp_rep1.git' | - | 0 | 183 | 1271 | cache:miss, clone, ssh:user:id:1 | 156 | o9qsm4 |
{noformat}

Git operation using an +Access Key+
{noformat}
172.17.0.1 | ssh | i@326W7Ox388x83x0 | b69a0c4a7aa114a0 | 2018-01-04 06:28:30,819 | SSH - git-upload-pack '/tp1/tp_rep1.git' | - | - | - | - | - | - | 1239iho |
172.17.0.1 | ssh | o@326W7Ox388x83x0 | b69a0c4a7aa114a0 | 2018-01-04 06:28:31,053 | SSH - git-upload-pack '/tp1/tp_rep1.git' | - | 0 | 183 | 1271 | cache:miss, clone, ssh:user:id:52 | 234 | 1239iho |
{noformat}

h3. Actual Results
The username is not added to the access log, the field shows an empty value instead {{ - }}.

Git operation using an +SSH Key+
{noformat}
# push operation
172.17.0.1 | ssh | i@16KZBADx289x149x0 | - | 2018-01-04 04:49:15,042 | SSH - git-receive-pack '/tp/tp_rep1.git' | "SSH-2.0-OpenSSH_7.4" | - | - | - | - | - | 1sqzc2 |
172.17.0.1 | ssh | o@16KZBADx289x149x0 | - | 2018-01-04 04:49:15,701 | SSH - git-receive-pack '/tp/tp_rep1.git' | "SSH-2.0-OpenSSH_7.4" | 0 | 855 | 197 | push, ssh:user:id:1 | 659 | 1sqzc2 |
# clone operation
172.17.0.1 | ssh | i@16KZBADx292x170x0 | - | 2018-01-04 04:52:12,345 | SSH - git-upload-pack '/tp/tp_rep1.git' | "SSH-2.0-OpenSSH_7.4" | - | - | - | - | - | uon561 |
172.17.0.1 | ssh | o@16KZBADx292x170x0 | - | 2018-01-04 04:52:12,552 | SSH - git-upload-pack '/tp/tp_rep1.git' | "SSH-2.0-OpenSSH_7.4" | 0 | 207 | 1341 | cache:miss, clone, ssh:user:id:1 | 207 | uon561 |
{noformat}

Git operation using an +Access Key+
{noformat}
172.17.0.1 | ssh | i@16KZBADx380x269x0 | - | 2018-01-04 06:20:47,522 | SSH - git-upload-pack '/tp/tp_rep1.git' | "SSH-2.0-OpenSSH_7.4" | - | - | - | - | - | 114uesv |
172.17.0.1 | ssh | o@16KZBADx380x269x0 | - | 2018-01-04 06:20:47,618 | SSH - git-upload-pack '/tp/tp_rep1.git' | "SSH-2.0-OpenSSH_7.4" | 0 | 207 | 1341 | cache:hit, clone, refs, ssh:user:id:2 | 96 | 114uesv |
{noformat}

h3.Workaround
The id in the label field can be used to retrieve the username or the access key used to perform the operation.

For example, in the {{cache:miss, clone, ssh:user:id:1}} label, the id is {{1}}.

This can be matched against the {{user_id}} in one of the following tables:
- {{sta_normal_user}} for Bitbucket Server users
- {{sta_service_user}} for access keys (see [How to read the Bitbucket Server Log Formats|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserverkb/how-to-read-the-bitbucket-server-log-formats-779171668.html] for details)

The id will be unique across the two tables.
fields.summary: For ssh operations, the access log does not contain the username

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

In Bitbucket, it is possible to have multiple application links to Jira. Due to this, it is possible to have a commit with a description pointing to an Issue Key which is present in more than one Jira instance. In this circumstance, the following logic can be observed - [Linking Bitbucket Server with JIRA|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/linking-bitbucket-server-with-jira-776640408.html]

{quote}If Bitbucket Server is linked with multiple JIRA Software instances and the projects happen to have the same key, only the issue from the instance marked as PRIMARY will be displayed. See [Making a primary link for links to the same application type|https://confluence.atlassian.com/applinks/making-a-primary-link-for-links-to-the-same-application-type-350519784.html].{quote}

However, this may not be comprehensive enough; it is unclear what happens if the Issue Key is shared between two Jira instances for example, while a third Jira instance is the PRIMARY.

(!) Ultimately, there is no easy way for a user to specify, or identify, which Jira instance to link a commit to in the circumstance where there are multiple instances with the specified issue key.

h3. Suggested Solution

In the Bitbucket UI, it would be valuable to present the user with an alert or other visual indicator indicating that the Jira issue key the commit is linked to is present in more than one Jira instance. 

h3. Why this is important
 
Users may unexpectedly find commits linked in their Jira issues when those issues inadvertently share the same issue key as the intended issue from another instance. Having greater visibility of this circumstance in Bitbucket can alleviate this confusion.
fields.summary: Warn or notify users when commit is linked to issue key present in multiple different Jira instances

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Installing Bitbucket Server on a Windows server shows an option to install it as a Data Center or Smart Mirror.

Running Bitbucket Data Center on a Windows server is *+not+ supported* as mentioned on the [Supported platforms|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/supported-platforms-776640981.html] page:
{quote}
Microsoft Windows is not supported for Bitbucket Data Center / 500+ Enterprise tiers.
{quote}


h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Install Bitbucket Server on Windows

h3. Expected Results
The Data Center and the Smart Mirror options are not presented. 

h3. Actual Results
The Data Center and the Smart Mirror options are available and can be selected:
!upload.png|width=400px! 
 
h3.Workaround
Don't select the Data Center and Smart Mirror options.
fields.summary: Windows installer offers Data Center and Smart Mirroring installation and upgrade options

fields.description:
As mentioned by one of our customers in BSERV-10334, [Markdown syntax guide|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/markdown-syntax-guide-776639995.html] of Bitbucket Server 5.6 still says:

{quote}Paragraphs are separated by empty lines. Within a paragraph it's possible to have a line break,
simply press <return> for a new line.

For example,
like this.{quote}

h4. Actual behaviour

Simply pressing <return> will create a soft line break but doesn't start a new paragraph. A user should press <return> twice to start a new paragraph.
fields.summary: Markdown syntax guide should correctly describe difference between soft and hard line breaks

fields.description:
h3. Summary

In markdown, if a list contains a text enclosed in '< >' (E.g: <text>), the markdown lists rendering breaks. For example, when trying to render the following on Bitbucket Server:

{noformat}
* List 1
    1. Point 1 
    2. Point 2 <Text>
    3. Point 3
  
* List 2
    1. Point 1
    2. Point 2
    3. Point 3
  
* List 3
    1. Point 1
    2. Point 2
    3. Point 3
{noformat}

will show as the following on Bitbucket:

 !Screen Shot 2017-12-29 at 8.11.13 PM.png|thumbnail! 

Seems the <text> got stripped out of the renderer, and the lists doesn't show correctly for some reason.
fields.summary: Markdown lists rendering broken if the list contains '<text>'

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian status as of June 2019|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3c78b5|titleBGColor=#3c78b5|bgColor=#e7f4fa}

Hi everyone,

Thanks for voting and commenting on this suggestion. Your input in the comments helps us understand how this affects you and what you're hoping to accomplish with Bitbucket Server.

We spend a significant amount of time on an ongoing basis to determine our product investments in Bitbucket Server. Unfortunately, we are not currently planning to address this suggestion in near future. I understand that this may be disappointing, but we believe it’s important for us to be open, honest and transparent with our customers. Product feedback is collected from a number of different sources and is evaluated when planning the product roadmap. You can [learn more about our process here|https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/110373/how-does-the-jira-team-use-jira-atlassian-com]. 

Cheers,
Imran Khan
Product Manager - Bitbucket Server and Data Center

{panel}

Original description:

Git has convention "Co-Authored-By"
{quote}We encourage the use of Co-Authored-By: name <name@example.com> in commit messages to indicate people who worked on a particular patch. It's a convention for recognizing multiple authors, and our projects would encourage the stats tools to observe it when collecting statistics.
{quote}
[https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages#Including_external_references]

 

Actually, I can put "Co-Authored-By" to commit message, but I see it as plain-text.

!Screenshot 2017-12-28 21.14.07_preview.png!

Here "Leonid Mamaev" is link to profile, while "Oleg Tsarev" - just plain-text.

 

I propose to make "Oleg Tsarev" second author of commit with link to him profile.

 

How to do it?

 

Let's look to commit deeper
{code:java}
commit 54ddc1e312e23df92bc0894785dbf3c6e16e9b83 (tag: DEVEL_20171228195255, tag: DEVEL_20171228195249, ot-bazel-tests-research)
Author: Leonid Mamaev <leonid@Leonids-MacBook-Pro.local>
Date: Wed Dec 13 13:30:28 2017 +0100

DEV-2986: [*] bazel: new python tests
Co-Authored-By: Oleg Tsarev <ot@project-plato.com>{code}
This commit created by "Oleg Tsarev"

He created it using "git commit --author="Leonid Mamaev <leonid@Leonids-MacBook-Pro.local>"

Bitbucket detected this string from commit and correctly link commit to Leonid profile.

I propose to parse also "Co-Authored-By" from commit message in exactly same way and link it as second (or third, or 4th) commit author.

I am talking only about Bitbucket web-interface
fields.summary: Support "Co-Authored-By" in bitbucket web-interface

fields.description:
The project list currently only shows the name of each repo. I'd also like to see the number of open pull requests.

Use case:

I need to release several repositories within a project that have dependencies on each other. Currently I have to open every single repository one at a time, verify that there are no open pull requests.

I would like to see this directly from the project page.


There is a free plugin that does something similar but it should really be core functionality.

[https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/com.infusion.stash.stash-all-pull-requests/server/overview]
fields.summary: Project summary should show the # of open pull requests

fields.description:
I have a project repository on a bitbucket server behind a proxy. I am the administrator for the repository in concern. The ask was to freeze a particular release branch (say, release/1.0) and create a new release branch (say, release/2.0) branching out of release/1.0.

Is there a way I can prevent the developers from creating a pull request for merging their feature changes to release/1.0? Instead, they should be creating pull requests to merge their changes only to release/2.0.

Like in the pull request creation page, the target branch dropdown should not show the value - release/1.0. But it should show release/2.0.
fields.summary: To provide the ability to prevent developers from pull request creation to a particular branch

fields.description: If all the reviewer approved the code , then after some time conflict occurs , after that developer resolve the conflict only (not added any other code change ). Then merge button should be enabled
fields.summary: Bitbucket merge button

fields.description: If QA build on bamboo is failed, Bitbucket merge button should be disable or a notification should be there to inform developer that bamboo build is failed .
fields.summary: Bitbucket communication with bamboo

fields.description:
Customers are asking if we can use the mode from the tree object to detect when something is a SYMLINK and not a file, making it visible on the UI that the object is a SYMLINK.

This would clear any confusion for users navigating the UI.
fields.summary: Make BitBucket show that an Object is a SYMLINK on the UI by reading the mode from the tree object

fields.description:
h3. Summary

In 5.6+ of Bitbucket Server, the option to synchronize a fork is not functional. When selecting *{{synchronize}}* you receive the pop-up to select Merge, Rebase, or Discard. When attempting to select one of these options, nothing happens.

h3. Environment
* v5.6+ Bitbucket Server
* Any browser

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create fork
# Make changes so that forks differ in content
# Access the forked repository *{{Commits}}* screen
# Select the *{{Synchronize}}* button
# Select the synchronize strategy
# Click *{{Merge}}*

h3. Expected Results

The repository is merged with the changes from the upstream.

h3. Actual Results

Nothing happens. No data is written to the application logs, to HAR files, or to the javascript console output. The synchronize strategy window remains open. 

h3.Workaround

Not at this time.
fields.summary: In 5.6+ of Bitbucket Server, the option to synchronize a fork is not functional.

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian status as of Oct 2020|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3c78b5|titleBGColor=#3c78b5|bgColor=#e7f4fa}
Hi everyone, 

[Bitbucket Server and Data Center 7.7|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/bitbucket-server-7-7-release-notes-1026037684.html#BitbucketServer7.7releasenotes-jupyter] onwards, we support rendering of [Jupyter notebooks|https://jupyter-notebook.readthedocs.io/en/stable/examples/Notebook/What%20is%20the%20Jupyter%20Notebook.html]. Just commit a {{.ipynb}} file to a new or existing repository in Bitbucket to view the rendered notebook.

Cheers,
 Imran Khan 
 Product Manager - Bitbucket Server and Data Center
{panel}
*Original description:* 
 Github now supports rich rendering of jupyter notebooks:

[https://github.com/blog/1995-github-jupyter-notebooks-3]

And Bitbucket (cloud version) seems to also [support it now|https://bitbucket.org/site/master/issues/11318/enable-rich-rendering-of-jupyter-notebooks]. Jupyter notebooks are increasingly used as a format for documentation, sharing computations, and reproducible data science in general.

The problem is that there's no support for this yet in Bitbucket Server. There's a plugin out there, but it is not very good, it can only render some notebooks, many of them render just as a blank page. Also, its LaTeX/MathJax support seems to be defective, equations are being displayed as raw LaTeX.

Note that GitHub has over 650000 notebooks shared on their website. This format is clearly becoming mainstream.
fields.summary: Enable rich rendering of Jupyter notebooks in Bitbucket Server

fields.description:
Set up and configure a Bitbucket Server instance on AWS using Amazon's Elasticsearch service
Make sure to use AWS Request signing (configure an AWS Region in the bitbucket properties) for the authentication between Bitbucket Server and Elasticsearch

Verify that the connection is successful by clicking the Test button.
However, in the Troubleshooting and Support Tools page of Bitbucket Server Admin it shows "connection-result AUTHENTICATION_ERROR"

The reason is that the Search plugin's Support Info request is only using Username/Password authentication to test the connection to Elasticsearch, and is not using the AWS Region which is configured
fields.summary: Search plugin does not support AWS region authentication in the Support Info request

fields.description:
h3. Summary
When the empty file has been committed to the repository the Edit button in online editor is never gets enabled.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a new text file
# Commit it and push it to the Bitbucket managed repository
# Open the file in Bitbucket web interface

h3. Expected Results
The Edit button is active and start the online editor.
h3. Actual Results
The Edit button is disabled.


h3. Workaround
Please avoid committing empty files or just put the while space symbol inside the empty file before commit.
fields.summary: Edit button is disabled if the source file is empty

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Currently the variables JAVA_KEYSTORE, JAVA_KEYSTORE_PASSWORD, JAVA_TRUSTSTORE and JAVA_TRUSTSTORE_PASSWORD which can be set in set-jmx-opts.sh are working only for the JMX settings.
It would be good to have similar variables to set the keystore and trustore for the application itself as it used to be with Tomcat: $STASH_HOME/conf/catalina.properties as it's not possible to set the trustore through bitbucket.properties due to https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-boot/issues/6493

h3. Suggested Solution
Please implement the variables to set the trustore just by the path without using JVM_SUPPORT_RECOMMENDED_ARGS as it designed to have only support advised values.
fields.summary: Allow to set the truststore and the keystore though the variable instead of JVM option

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
In Bitbucket Server 5.5 [personal access tokens|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/personal-access-tokens-939515499.html] have been introduced. They can be used to replace passwords over https, or to authenticate using the Bitbucket Server REST API over Basic Auth.  However the tokens cannot be used for administrative access REST endpoints like /rest/access-tokens/latest/users/admin or 
/rest/api/1.0/admin/permissions/groups

The error message: {{Tokens may not have the following permission: ADMIN}}

h3. Suggested Solution
Please provide the access tokens with the global ADMIN permissions.

h3. Why this is important
Using tokens for the system management automation is more comfortable and secure rather than login-password authentication.
fields.summary: Create admin personal tokens for admin endpoints in Bitbucket Server REST API

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
The Docker container for Bitbucket Server (https://bitbucket.org/atlassian/docker-atlassian-bitbucket-server) allows to install a Data Center instance. 
However, it does not provide details on how to perform a complete installations (e.g. more than one node, a Load balancer).

h3. Suggested Solution
Provide a detailed guide on how to install an entire Data Center instance or a set of Docker containers and the related instructions.
For example, the [Install Bitbucket Data Center|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/install-bitbucket-data-center-872139817.html] page provides a set of detailed instructions when installing on a server.


h3. Workaround
Follow the Data Center installation guide to install all the required components for a Data Center Docker installation.
fields.summary: As an admin, I would like an easier way to setup a Data Center Docker instance

fields.description:
h3. Summary
The E-diff option in Bitbucket Server does not highlight all the changes in a csv.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a csv file with some differences in the source and target branch of a pull request

In the example below the following changes have been applied to the file in the source branch:
- line 2: replaced {{01/18/2918}} with {{01/19/2918}} - no e-diff is displayed
- line 6: replaced {{Employee Only}} with {{Employee EEOnly}}
- line 8: replaced {{Employee Only}} with {{Employee EEOnly}} and {{marshmallowOne}} with {{marshmallowTwo}}

This is the output of the Git diff command performed by Bitbucket Server:
{noformat}
git diff -C --color=never -U10 --dst-prefix=dst:// --src-prefix=src:// e004b7c3ec4b41a6acf6404a8b1041c26255f8f6 851949fd4137cd25db87dae0d863131f62927279 -- CsvDiff.csv
...
diff --git src://CsvDiff.csv dst://CsvDiff.csv
index c3cd6e2..fc6a69e 100644
--- src://CsvDiff.csv
+++ dst://CsvDiff.csv
@@ -1,9 +1,9 @@
 01/2018,$132.00,,01/18/2918,Verify some text,Cup cake, Employee Only,Tart chocolate bar candy donut marshmallowOne,Yes,91/91/2917
-01/2018,$132.00,,01/18/2918,Verify some text,Cup cake, Employee Only,Tart chocolate bar candy donut marshmallowOne,Yes,91/91/2917
 01/2018,$132.00,,01/19/2918,Verify some text,Cup cake, Employee Only,Tart chocolate bar candy donut marshmallowOne,Yes,91/91/2917
+01/2018,$102.00,,01/19/2918,Verify some text,Cup cake, Employee Only,Tart chocolate bar candy donut marshmallowOne,Yes,91/91/2917
 01/2018,$132.00,,01/18/2918,Verify some text,Cup cake, Employee Only,Tart chocolate bar candy donut marshmallowOne,Yes,91/91/2917
 01/2018,$132.00,,01/18/2918,Verify some text,Cup cake, Employee Only,Tart chocolate bar candy donut marshmallowOne,Yes,91/91/2917
+01/2018,$132.00,,01/18/2918,Verify some text,Cup cake, Employee EEOnly,Tart chocolate bar candy donut marshmallowOne,Yes,91/91/2917
 01/2018,$132.00,,01/18/2918,Verify some text,Cup cake, Employee Only,Tart chocolate bar candy donut marshmallowOne,Yes,91/91/2917
-01/2018,$132.00,,01/18/2918,Verify some text,Cup cake, Employee Only,Tart chocolate bar candy donut marshmallowOne,Yes,91/91/2917
-01/2018,$132.00,,01/18/2918,Verify some text,Cup cake, Employee Only,Tart chocolate bar candy donut marshmallowOne,Yes,91/91/2917
+01/2018,$132.00,,01/18/2918,Verify some text,Cup cake, Employee EEOnly,Tart chocolate bar candy donut marshmallowTwo,Yes,91/91/2917
 01/2018,$132.00,,01/18/2918,Verify some text,Cup cake, Employee Only,Tart chocolate bar candy donut marshmallowOne,Yes,91/91/2917
{noformat}

h3. Expected Results
The applied changes are highlighted.

h3. Actual Results
The following diffs are displayed. 

+Unified view+
!CsvDiff.png|width=400px! 

+Side by side view+
!CsvDiff_sideBySide.png|width=400px! 

h3.Workaround
- Download the files and compare them in an external tool

fields.description:
h3. Summary
The clone URL is empty (blank) when the following conditions are met:
- no ssh key is available for the user, therefore SSH is not available as a clone protocol
- a mirror URL is selected

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Setup a user with no ssh key
# Setup a mirror
# Attempt to perform a clone and switch to one of the available mirrors from the "Clone from" drop down
!BSERV10478_CloneURLvisible.png|width=150px! 

h3. Expected Results
The clone URL is prefilled.

h3. Actual Results
The clone URL is empty.
!BSERV10478_CloneURLmissing.png|width=150px! 
 
h3. Notes
Switching to a different mirror or to the upstream server will not populate the clone URL.
To obtain the upstream server URL, select "Primary server" from the "Clone from" drop down and refresh the page.

h3.Workaround
The following alternatives can be used:
- manually retrieve the mirror URL
- add an SSH key to the user
fields.summary: Clone URL is empty when no ssh key is available for the user and a mirror URL is selected

fields.description:
It looks like if X days and 0..24 hours have passed since an event, Bitbucket will display this event as "X days ago". Although this is logically consistent, consider the following scenario with three Pull Requests:

!image-2017-12-18-11-39-17-458.png!

This screenshot was taken on Monday at 11:00. All these PRs were last updated on the same day (Friday), but the first two after 11:00 and the last one before 11:00. This difference of a few hours translates into a displayed difference of a whole day, creating the illusion that the PRs were updated on separate days.

IMO after 24 hours have passed the exact hour of the event is not displayed anyways, so it should be ignored from the calculation altogether, and only the day part should be taken into account, which would result in the (for me expected) result where all three PRs are displayed as "last updated 3 days ago".

Of course, the "real best" solution would be to [implement the ability to disable relative dates|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BSERV-4477].
fields.summary: Inconsistent display of relative dates

h3. Problem Definition
Currently, Bitbucket Server supports PostgreSQL up to:
(/) 9.4 - 9.6
(/) 9.3.6+
(/) 9.2

PostgreSQL 10 is available and users would like to see support for this as well.

h3. Suggested Solution
Provide support for PostgreSQL 10
fields.summary: Support for PostgreSQL 10

fields.description:
h3. Problem

On the pull request page, on the diff tab -- if the keys 'J' and 'K' are being hit too fast, that may cause the diff page to reload and get stuck in a loop. This can be reproduced on Chrome, Firefox and Safari.

On Firefox and Safari, when the page is stuck on the loop, clicking the 'close tab' will just close the tab immediately -- However, on Chrome, the tab (and the entire browser) will just be stuck in a loop, and the only way to get out is to force close Chrome.

 !Screen Shot 2017-12-15 at 5.34.55 PM.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: In Pull Request Diff tab, hitting fast 'J' then 'K' will cause the page to reload and stuck in a loop

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian status as of July 2020|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#deebff|titleBGColor=#deebff|bgColor=#ffffff}
Good news! In Bitbucket Data Center 7.0 we added Advanced Auditing feature which helps admins and security teams to have a global view on auditing events. Pull request comment events are also audited if you set _Level of coverage -> End user activity -> Full_.

You can find more information in the Bitbucket Server 7.0 [release notes|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/bitbucket-server-7-0-release-notes-990546638.html] and Advanced Auditing [documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/audit-logging-in-bitbucket-server-776640417.html].

Anton Genkin
 Product Manager Bitbucket Server
{panel}
*Original message*
 My company works within the regulated space, and we have observed that comments can be deleted from Bitbucket Pull Requests possibly losing important documentary evidence. Besides having the ability to disable the deletion of comments as per related issue BSERV-8513 it would be highly desirable for Pull Request comment lifecyle events to be logged.

Having reviewed [https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/audit-events-in-bitbucket-server-776640423.html] that lists the events logged by Bitbucket Server for a Pull Request there is currently nothing there relating to the logging of events relating to comments. At my company we believe that there should be.
|PullRequestEvent|Fired at different points in the pull request lifecycle (declined, merged, opened, reopened, rescoped [code updated], updated, approved, unapproved, participants updated).|

The reasoning here, is that Pull Request evidence can help show the design reasoning behind how an implementation took shape. It is important evidence, it should be considered a potential quality record, just like a Jira issue is and this is why we need similar full logging for pull requests and their comments.
fields.summary: Pull Request Comment Audit Log

fields.description:

As a result, normal users are able to see pages but their admin users aren't able to see any pages until after the licensed user count is calculated.

Save the licensed user count and reload it on startup so admins can use the app immediately.

fields.description:
We are *missing bugs* that reviewers reported in BitBucket Pull Requests -- due to a nuance of this tool. We like this tool! But please help us catch _all_ of the bugs we report.
h3. PROBLEM DESCRIPTION:

Pull Requests (PR) are starting to feel too complicated to be thorough, when we have a lot of comments on multiple files and multiple commits.  We need a way to know we've addressed all comments, but the way Bitbucket displays them sometimes makes them hard to see.  For instance, during a Pull Request, our natural inclination is to review a file from top to bottom. The Overview page is listed in reverse chronological order of when comments were made, which would be inconvenient for a comprehensive code review with multiple files and reviewers. So instead of using the overview page, we go straight to the Diff page, and select the files to review in order, using "Show Diff of 'All changes in this pull request'".

Unfortunately, I just learned that that setting does NOT show all the review comments if there are multiple commits. If some comments are made in a BitBucket Pull Request, then the author uploads corrections for those comments, and then additional comments are made: not all the comments will be displayed. If we don't realize the problem (which has happened), we may never review all the comments. Our expectation was that I would see them all, so the interface was not intuitive enough to help us get it right.  We need to go through the Overview page to make sure all were covered.  But with a hundred comments, all colored the same, in order of comment creation -- it is tedious and error-prone to search.
h3. POSSIBLE SOLUTIONS:

All the comments are on the Overview page, but that page is not in an efficient format for large reviews. If it had the ability to *change its sort order* to "By File" in addition to the default "Reverse Chronological", we could more easily find the missing information.

Similarly, maybe a checkbox on the Overview page could *enable comment display for each commit*, so they could be cycled through.

Another option would be to have a *Diff view that somehow marked how many unique comments exist on each commit*, similar to the red circle with a white number currently employed in the top-right of my screen, that indicates the number of unapproved Pull Requests I have that are outstanding.

Another option may be to *allow comments to be marked as read or resolved*, and then display a "number of comments not read by reviewers" count so we can make sure it is zero before approving a PR.

Another option would be to allow a *Diff View to accumulate changes and comments from multiple commits.* That sounds technically challenging, though it would be nice.

Another option may be to *carry forward comments with each new commit, until they are marked resolved.* That would be neat, but seems technically challenging.

Thank you for considering this problem.
fields.summary: Pull Request Comments Were Missed

fields.description:
Do Pull-Request right and build the result of the merge of source and target.
 Actually the builds blocking a PR does not give any sense of security. Because the build is only run for the source. The real safety is to run the builds against a merge of source and target. I dont know why this required feature is missing in bitbucket/bamboo - So here are the requirements:
 * Run Builds of PRs aigainst the merge-result of source and target
 * Let us define which Build-Plans must have green builds per target-branch.
 * Let us choose when to invalidate a build (changes in source, target or in both)
 * Let us choose to auto trigger a new build on build-invalidation

This is a must have feature for "real" source-control/build system.
fields.summary: Pull-Requests with Target-Merging

fields.description:
Hi,

We recently installed Bitbucket Data Center 5.2.2 at a client. The client has a very large user directory which (due to a bug in the SSO app from resolution) needs to be synced to Bitbucket. So now we have 43,000+ users in the database. When you now go to the user administration (https://<bitbucket>/admin/users the page times out.

In Jira in which we have the same user base, this does not happen, because in Jira only the first 100 users are queried. Furthermore managing users in Jira has a richer experience than in Bitbucket.

E.g. filtering in Jira:
 !image-2017-12-07-09-41-26-759.png|width=800!
 Visible groups, action menu
 !image-2017-12-07-09-43-07-746.png|width=800!
  

Regards,

Rudy Holtkamp

This ticket has been created after request of Tiago Vitorino (tvitorino@atlassian.com)
fields.summary: Make user management experience like Jira

fields.description:
Hi,

We've installed Bitbucket Data Center 5.2.2 at a client, mainly for the smart-mirroring option.

What we would like to see is that we can mirror on a per repository level instead of a per project level. Our projects have repositories which belong logically together. Development takes place around the globe, but not all repositories in one project needs to be synced to the mirrors. In some cases in is not even allowed to sync them (export-rules/legislation). I understand that the current implementation was done for ease of administration. But it has a severe downside. Now we have to create several projects and place repositories in them which may be synced to one site but not to another. It is really hard now to keep track of it and I can't explain it to the developers.

Next to the administration hassle and user experience we also have bandwidth problems. In some cases we have projects where a few very large repo's are present (>1GB). These do not have to be synced to a mirror, but others do. Now we have to sync all of them, which has a severe impact on the bandwidth we have and performance is drastically reduced. 

So please give the system administrators (or even better the project/repo administrators) the possibility to mirror individual repositories. Giving repository or project administrators the option to mirror their repository would also be inline with the paradigm shift I see in Jira (power to the project admins!)

Rudy Holtkamp

This issue has been created on suggestion of Tiago Vitorino (tvitorino@atlassian.com)
fields.summary: Mirroring should be possible on repository level

fields.description:
Hi,

Recently we have installed Jira, Confluence (both server) and Bitbucket Data Center (5.2.2) at a client. 
Zooming in on Bitbucket, we are using a PostgreSQL server which is shared between the other applications. The same goes for the file server. Our install directories are on the server disk and our home directory is mounted on the file server. Furthermore we are using the SSO plugin from resolution. So users via the GUI will be redirected to the IDP and rest api calls are not. (see picture below for an overview)
 
Ssh traffic (git operations) is also immediately forwarded to Bitbucket. We do not allow https cloning. *Preferable we don't want to allow Basic Authentication at all.* The new version of Bitbucket sounded like a good solution (with personal tokens) but I talked to Ada Chen (Atlassian) and she told us that we cannot disable basic authentication. And I also heard that personal tokens are not coming to Jira and Confluence (which. From a security perspective it would be great to be able to disable basic authentication and use personal tokens instead (for REST API calls) for all Atlassian applications. 
 
!image-2017-12-07-09-11-35-726.png!
 
Kind regards
Rudy Holtkamp (TMC)
This ticket has been created after request of Tiago Vitorino (tvitorino@atlassian.com)
fields.summary: Ability to drop Basic Authentication and only use personal tokens

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

XFS filesystem fit the prerequisites (volume capable of atomic (block level) snapshots) for the DIY backup. But there are no example script provided for XFS in [https://bitbucket.org/atlassianlabs/atlassian-bitbucket-diy-backup/src]. 
h3. Suggested Solution

Provide an example script for XFS similar as for other filesystem like EBS and ZFS
h3. Workaround

Modify any of the existing example given, like ZFS
fields.summary: Provide an example DIY Backup script for XFS filesystem

fields.description:
When an exception is thrown while trying to create a new repository, the {{Throwable}} that caused it is not included on the {{CommandFailedException}}. This makes troubleshooting failed creation unnecessarily difficult.

*Note*: the full stack trace as well as the error will only be displayed when the *debug* log level ({{Bitbucket Server Administration > Logging and profiling}} and click to check/enable the {{Enable debug logging}} option) is on
fields.summary: Repository creation exceptions don't include their causes

fields.description: It would be very useful to be able to include people in a Pull Request (PR) as a watcher.  The person is included for their benefit so they are informed of the changes but are not expected to participate as a reviewer.  Additionally, just as automatic reviewers can be specified in Workzone Settings, so should we be able to specify automatic watchers.  Lastly, the watchers would be listed in PR, separately from reviewers (as watchers can be listed in JIRA).
fields.summary: As a developer, I would like to able to designate watchers as well as reviewers for a pull request

fields.description:
On the Bitbucket Pull Request pages, there is plenty of useful information — but what's missing is the repository the pull request is for. If you — like me — work with multiple repositories, and look at multiple pull requests per day, it's easy to get confused. Basically the only way to know in which repo a pull request is, is to look at the URL.

I would love color coding of some sorts (e.g. the left side bar could have some user-defined color, depending on what repo I'm in?), but at least the repository name should be visible somewhere, prominently, at the top of the page.
fields.summary: Pull request page does not show repository name

fields.description:
When dev1 has opened a pull request from e.g. a feature branch to the develop branch, then dev2 has approved the pull request, and afterwards dev1 pushes another change to the branch, the pull request is marked as unapproved. This is sensible behaviour, but there is one thing about it that I don't like, and which leads to confusion: It is not obvious, that the "Unapproved" was an automatic action done by the system. It looks like the person, who had previously approved the pull request, had now manually unapproved it again, without providing a comment.

!https://connect.bosch.com/forums/ajax/download?nodeId=e4113917-81a0-4462-9090-d37536d7ef8c|id=img_38835539141512138281010!

IMO it would be much better if there would be an additional remark (e.g. instead of UNAPPROVED, the label could read UNAPPROVED AUTOMATICALLY or something).
fields.summary: Auto-unapproved after push should be marked as such

fields.description:
They show up as brown in their new locations, but it isn't immediately obvious how to discover what the file's former location was.  Instead of having to accidentally discover this by hovering on the MOVED lozenge, maybe this should just render more like a file comment or conflict notice?

*Reporter*: Chris Fuller
*E-mail*: [mailto:cfuller@atlassian.com]
fields.summary: When files are moved, you can't tell in the PR where they came from

fields.description: Sometimes, we may need put more fine-granular restrictions such as not being able to edit configuration files in the source. Is it possible that we can enable/disable UI edit feature depending on the filetype that can be provided in project/repository settings?

h3.How to Replicate

- git checkout -b bugfix/hiptest2 (create new branch)
- vi file1 (make a change)
- git add .
- git commit -m "Test"
- git push origin bugfix/hiptest2

h3.Expected behavior

In version pre-5.x, the new branch creation was noted in the Hipchat room and the notification for the event was also published in the room with no errors in the logs

h3.Actual Behavior

The notification for the event makes it to Hipchat but the branch creation is not noted in the room and an error for a missing commit is seen in the logs
fields.summary: Bitbucket Server 5.x doesn't ignore missing commits when pushing notifications to Hipchat

Please see SSP-26218 for more details.

fields.description:
It is possible to bypass the bitbucket auto-unapprove plugin via minimal brute-force because it is relying on asynchronous events on the back-end. 
 This allows an attacker to merge any code into unsuspecting repositories.

All versions before version 3.0.1 of the auto-unapprove plugin are affected, however since the auto-unapprove plugin is not bundled with Bitbucket Server it does not affect any particular version of Bitbucket
fields.summary: Race condition in auto-unapprove plugin - CVE-2017-16857

fields.description:
This affects instances running with Git 2.11+

When a {{PreRepositoryHook}} attempts to execute a command to read objects from a repository other than the one which is the subject of the push, the git commands fail because the relevant objects cannot be found.

Git 2.11+ introduced quarantine pushes. This means that git will no longer write the objects in a push directly into the repository. Instead the objects are written to a temporary quarantine directory while the pre-receive hooks are executed. Once all hooks complete successfully the objects are copied to the repository.

The root cause of the issue is that in the context of a pre-receive hook a quarantine environment needs to be configured so that the git commands executed by Bitbucket Server will have access to the objects being pushed. Unfortunately this environment is always applied and it means that if a pre-receive hook attempts to access a different repository it will still read the objects from the push repository.

Workaround:

Have the pre-receive hook move the logic to a separate thread, perhaps using the {{ExecutorService}}. The pre-receive hook can then wait on the {{Future#get}} call. This should prevent the quarantine environment from being applied to the command.
fields.summary: Pre-receive hooks can only read objects from the repository being pushed to on Git 2.11+

fields.description:
hi,

based on my experience, companies in certain industries do not contribute at all to open source - specifically banks... i'm sure there are other industries the same can be said for.

this is due to concerns of code, trading algorithms, etc getting out of the bank... mailing of code externally is also blocked in many cases

maybe if there were extra controls or approvals process for code to be uploaded outside of the organisation through something centralised like Bitbucket, it would be easier to get banks and other such organisations to contribute more to open source projects
fields.summary: approval/control system for contributing to open source projects from within organisation such as banks

fields.description: Phabricator diffs have a super nice feature where if code is copied & pasted or moved around in a file, it shows a yellow bar along the side. This is really helpful for knowing that code has been reformatted and is not entirely new. It’s an unfortunate loss that Bitbucket diffs don’t seem to support this.
fields.summary: Bitbucket diff doesn't show copied code (Phabricator diffs do)

fields.description:
h3. Summary

When creating branch on Bitbucket, if the name of the created branch is too long (more than 100 characters), users get the error message "The ref name, once fully qualified, is limited to 100 characters" UI and gets stuck without any possibility to change the branch name

h3. Steps to Reproduce

# Create a branch with a long name (more than 100 characters)

h3. Expected Results
Users get an error that the branch name is too long, and is able to to edit the branch name on the same page

h3. Actual Results
Users get the error message "The ref name, once fully qualified, is limited to 100 characters" UI and gets stuck without any possibility to change the branch name

 !Screen Shot 2017-12-01 at 8.43.48 PM.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Workaround
Refresh the 'Create branch' page to be able to rename the branch to a shorter name
fields.summary: When trying to create a branch name which is too long (> 100 characters), the UI gets stuck without any possibility to change the branch name

h4. Actual Result

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
In the plugin [Bitbucket Server Auto Unapprove Plugin by Atlassian Labs|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/com.atlassian.stash.plugin.stash-auto-unapprove-plugin/server/overview] the setting "Unapprove automatically on new changes" exists only on the repository level.
h3. Suggested Solution
Implement "Unapprove automatically on new changes" on the project level.
h3. Why this is important
It will make more comfortable for users to set this permissions to the projects with big number of repositories.
fields.summary: Extend Bitbucket Server Auto Unapprove Plugin to the project level

The license is added successfully.

Workaround:

Use the [REST API|https://developer.atlassian.com/static/rest/bitbucket-server/latest/bitbucket-rest.html#idm45669361007200] to add a new license if you need to update it.

An example REST call would be the following:

{code}
curl -u <username>:<password> -X POST -H "Content-Type: application/json" -d '{"license":"<license key>"}' <Bitbucket base url>/<context path>/rest/api/1.0/admin/license
{code}

Ensure the user performing the command has admin permissions and the data in the -d tag has the correct quotes (single quotes for the entire payload double quotes for the JSON key:value pair)
fields.summary: Unlimited User Licenses Break admin/license page

fields.description:
One of my responsibilities is to review all pull requests which range from 3 to 15 per day. While in the Pull Request Overview page I would like the ability to copy the branch name similar to that in the repository browse view. This would make it much easier to copy the name so that checking out the branch locally to test can be done more quickly and without errors.

Presently my methodology is to select the text on the page but more often than not the branch name is ellipses or extraneous text is included and when pasted in shell, caused errors.

Attached is a mockup of the feature.

!PR-with-actions.png!
fields.summary: Add ability to copy the branch name or url to checkout a branch from a Pull Request Overview

fields.description:
I'm been playing around with webhooks in the latest version - working really well so far!

I would like to deploy the software from a PR event, but ideally this would happen after the CI build rather than immediately after opening the PR.

Can you add a 'Build complete' event type for pull requests?
fields.summary: Add Build event webhook

fields.description:
When reviewing PR's, there are often times a number of files that are mostly irrelevant to the review, EG .csproj files in a .NET solution, or do not need to be reviewed at all.  It would be great to have the ability to exclude such files from the full view diff in order to reduce clutter when reviewing code.  Something as simple as checkboxes next to the file names that would remove the files from the diff when unchecked would do the trick.

 

This would also allow you to only focus on a limited set of files at a time, which can be useful if trying to follow code paths in the PR.
fields.summary: As a PR reviewer, I want the ability to exclude files when viewing diffs

fields.description:
h3. Summary
If you cannot (or do not want to) use local storage on Windows platforms, you can use network storage. In [Bitbucket Server home directory|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/bitbucket-server-home-directory-776640890.html] we advise against using UNC paths and instead mapping the network drive to a local drive letter or using {{mklink}} to create a symbolic link pointing to the UNC path. If you decide to link to your network storage using {{mklink}} and you use this storage as the Bitbucket Server home directory, Bitbucket Server incorrectly determines the size of the storage (total and available size) for the shared home (instead of detecting the size of the network storage it detects the size of the volume on which the symbolic link is placed).

h3. Environment
* Bitbucket Server on Windows
* Bitbucket home directory hosted on a shared network linked via mklink
h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Install Bitbucket Server on Windows
# Create an empty directory on any volume, say {{C:\storage}} to be used as the Bitbucket home directory
# Open a command prompt and navigate to the directory created in step 2
# Run the following command: {{mklink /d bitbuckethome \\server\share}} (where {{bitbuckethome}} is the name of the link that will be created and {{\\server\share}} is the UNC path to the shared storage location that will host the Bitbucket home directory
# Update the {{%BITBUCKET_HOME%}} environment variable so it points to {{C:\storage\bitbuckethome}}
# Start Bitbucket Server
# Create a support zip

h3. Expected Results
When looking at the {{application.xml}} contained in the support zip, the disk size information for the Bitbucket home directory and the Bitbucket shared home directory is the size information of the network drive.

h3. Actual Results
The disk size information for the Bitbucket home directory is the size information for the network drive, but the size information for the shared home is that of the local volume that contains the symbolic link, even though the shared home directory is a sub directory of the Bitbucket home, which is on the network location.

An example extract from the {{application.xml}} is below:
{code:xml}
<filesystem>
    <home>
      <path>C:\storage\bitbuckethome</path>
      <name>STORAGE</name>
      <description>STORAGE (\\server\share$)</description>
      <free-size>1000.00 GB</free-size>
      <total-size>900.00 GB</total-size>
      <type>NTFS</type>
    </home>
    <shared-home>
      <path>C:\storage\bitbuckethome\shared</path>
      <name>STORAGE</name>
      <description>STORAGE (C:)</description>
      <free-size>19.90 GB</free-size>
      <total-size>20.00 GB</total-size>
      <type>NTFS</type>
    </shared-home>
  </filesystem>
{code}

h3.Workaround

Other than using local storage rather than networked storage there is no known workaround.
fields.summary: Bitbucket Server incorrectly detects disk sizes on Windows if using a symbolic link

fields.description:
After creating a new project in Bitbucket Server, I attempt to import an existing repository from Bitbucket Cloud.

I choose the option "Select repositories"

The repository that I am importing from contains a large number of projects, and the UI only displays a small subset of these.

The subset displayed is completely unsorted.

There is no ability to sort, search or otherwise filter the output.

 

As I scroll down, new entries are loaded from the remote repository and when I eventually find the entry I am looking for I can import it successfully.

 

This feature could definitely use improvement.
fields.summary: When attempting to import existing repositories from Bitbucket Cloud, the results are unsorted

fields.description: If a HTTP 500 error (or really anything other than 404, 503, and 401 (it's handled in the REST util)) happens on the repo filter endpoint in Search, it should fallback to the core REST endpoint. Instead it will continue to re-request continuously.
fields.summary: HTTP statuses other than 404 and 503 cause infinite search requests on repository list

fields.description: Provide support for Support for Oracle Database 18c in Bitbucket Server
fields.summary: Support for Oracle Database 18c

fields.description: All comments show up in the "overview" tab, but when viewing the diff of a file, if the comment was made on a particular commit, you cannot see it without switching to that commit.  It would be nice to have a "view all comments" option, perhaps indicating that comments made on code that was deleted are no longer relevant.
fields.summary: View comments from ALL commits when viewing a file diff

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Bitbucket version for Windows use incorrect quotation approach in Git commands so all the quotation marks in the beginning and the end of the commit message are lost.
h3. Environment
Windows Server 2012, Windows 10, amd64
Oracle JRE 1.8.0_102-b14 
Oracle JRE 1.8.0_144-b01
OpenJDK 8 build b132

On Linux instances the issue cannot be reproduced.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Push a plain-text file to Bitbucket Server.
#  Browse to that file in the web UI.
# Click Edit.
# Type some more text in the web editor.
# Click Commit.
# Bitbucket Server asks for a commit message. Type the following, including quotation marks, and without leading or trailing spaces: "three" and "four"
# Click Commit.
# Click the Commits icon in the sidebar.


h3. Expected Results
The commit message is {{"three" and "four"}}
h3. Actual Results
The commit message is {{three" and "four}}

fields.description: In the "Controlling when pull requests can be merged" tutorial, when the {{I18nService}} is introduced in {{IsAdminMergeCheck}}, the {{getMessage}} call on line 33 should be replaced with a call to {{getText}}. {{getText}} accepts a fallback message; {{getMessage}} doesn't.
fields.summary: IsAdminMergeCheck example uses I18nService incorrectly

fields.description:
h3. Summary Smart commit in Bitbucket server overwrite all the occurrences of JIRA-keys and commitids even inside another markdown tages. h3. Steps to Reproduce # Create .md file and add to the the repository # Edit the content of the file with Bitbucket Editor or with standalone editor in a local copy # Commit the changes # Open the file in a source viewer in Bitbucket Server h3. Expected Results The following HTML is generated: {code:html}

See linkref.

{code} h3. Actual Results The following HTML is generated: {code:html}

See ISSUE-1] Description">linkref.

{code} The same thing works with commit ID. h3.Workaround No workaround currently available.
fields.summary: JIRA smart links and commitid overwritten with links even it's a part of another markdown object

fields.description:
h3. Description

As a Bitbucket administrator, I'd like to be able to log in as another user, to be able to see what screens are accessible to that user once he logs in.

This option is already available in Jira.
h3. Workaround

The only possible workaround at the moment is to use the user's credentials to get into his account.
fields.summary: Impersonate user

fields.description: I do not wan to fill something in comment just for creating of task
fields.summary: Create a task in a pull request without creating comment for a line of a code

fields.description:
Entering in [https://developer.atlassian.com/bitbucket/server/docs/] and clicking a directory for an older version of Bitbucket goes to a 404 error page.

E.g entering in 5.5.0 directory redirects to [https://developer.atlassian.com/bitbucket/server/docs/5.5.0/,] showing a "404 error".

The corrects URL should be https://developer.atlassian.com/bitbucket/server/docs/5.5.0/index.html
h1.
fields.summary: Update Bitbucket Server Docs Page to find older Bitbucket versions

fields.description:
Currently, a PR comments has all its HTML tags sanitised, even img tags.

By contrast, a README.md is rendered with a tag whitelist, enabling users to use HTML tags directly.

It would be really helpful (and more consistent) if PR comments supported HTML tags too. It's currently impossible to use things like {{<details>}} to put collapsible sections in a big comment.
fields.summary: Support a whitelist of HTML tags on PR comments

fields.description:
h3. Summary

There are some inconsistencies when trying to render the following in markdown:

{noformat}
line 1
line 2

line 3
line 4{noformat}

On [CommonMark dingus|http://spec.commonmark.org/dingus/], the above should be rendered as the following:
 !Screen Shot 2017-11-17 at 10.27.50 PM copy.png|thumbnail! 

However, on Bitbucket Server, similar markdown file will be rendered as the following instead:
 !Screen Shot 2017-11-17 at 10.27.06 PM.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Markdown Rendering Inconsistency

fields.description:
We often add device screenshots to Bitbucket comments to discuss about visual glitches and bugs. However, using screenshots from a retina device is painful, since these images are shown in full size within the Bitbucket discussion list.

 

It would be awesome if Bitbucket would automatically show an image thumbnail, as soon as an image exceeds a reasonable size. Clicking on the thumbnail should then reveal the original image.
fields.summary: Show large images as thumbnails in comments

fields.description:
h3. Summary

When using the AWS Bitbucket template, deploying a Mirror is not possible as the properties setting is not recognized.

h3. Environment
* AWS Cloudformation

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Go to AWS > Cloud Formation > Create Stack
# Apply the [template URL|http://atlassian-software.s3.amazonaws.com/templates/bitbucket/BitbucketServer.template]
# Either in the design template or in the UI add the setting for Bitbucket properties: *{{application.mode=mirror}}*
# After the stack is created, shell into the ec2 instance and view the bitbucket.properties file

h3. Expected Results

The properties setting should be detected and establish the instance as a Mirror.

h3. Actual Results

The application mode properties setting is ignored and a standard instance is created instead.
 
h3.Workaround

Run the installer manually to [setup a smart mirror|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/set-up-a-mirror-790632894.html].
fields.summary: When using the AWS Bitbucket template, deploying a Mirror is not possible as the properties setting is not recognized.

fields.description:
h3. Summary

When an user creates a new pull request and let's someone review it, that someone is (when not in need of a braille device) able to review code changes by a colored diff (red removed lines, green added / changed lines etc.)

That diff is rendered inside a table and is completely invisible for visually impaired users, so visually impaired users are unable to do code reviews.
h3. Steps to Reproduce

Opening the pull request, a new page opens:

{{bitbucket.domain.com/projects/<PROJECT>/repos/<REPOSITOR>/pull-requests/<NUMBER>/overview}}

There're 3 "tabs" below the top navigation menu: Overview, Diff, Commit

Opening these tabs is possible, though upon opening "Diff" the a table appears, at the left side the "Show diff of ..." and the real diff of the code at the right side.

The contents of right side with showing changes to the code isn't visible, also making comments isn't possible, because the element doesn't appear.
h3. Workaround

No workaround available at the moment
fields.summary: The diff of a pull request isn't accessible for users using a braille device

fields.description:
We are a product based software development company and looking out to explore Bitbucket

We are trying to migrate from Clearcase to BitBucket. This is first time we are exploring and need complete details and steps to carry out this task.

*Other relevant queries:*

*1. Is there any size limit for Private Repository?*

*2. How to get the History along with source code from Clearcase into Bitbucket?*

*3. We need to have a call setup for understanding this activity and discuss further on Pricing/Licensing/Support etc.*
fields.summary: ClearCase to BitBucket Migration

fields.description:
*Summary*

The [managing webhooks|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BitbucketServer/Managing+webhooks+in+Bitbucket+server?utm_campaign=in-app-help&utm_medium=in-app-help&utm_source=stash#ManagingwebhooksinBitbucketServer-webhooksecrets] page references an *{{Updated}}* event, and more, that does not exist according to our [Event payload|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BitbucketServer/Event+payload?utm_campaign=in-app-help&utm_medium=in-app-help&utm_source=stash#Eventpayload-repositoryevents] page and the Create Webhook page itself:

Image in our 5.5 documentation:
 !image-2017-11-14-19-53-08-612.png|thumbnail! 

Image in my 5.5 instance:
 !personal-instance.png|thumbnail! 

*Suggested Resolution*

Remove the reference to the events that are not available and update documentation screenshot to represent actual product view.
fields.summary: Managing webhooks page reference events that are not available
